newsitem.title: USA: Oracle shares rise on better-than-expected profit.
newsitem.headline: Oracle shares rise on better-than-expected profit.

text.p: Oracle Corp. shares rose 13 percent Friday after the database software company reported fiscal third-quarter earnings that matched Wall Street expectations and eased concerns about the company's outlook in coming months.
Shares of Oracle, the second-largest software company after Microsoft Corp., jumped $4.875 to $41 on Nasdaq, where it was the second-most active stock on volume of 17.3 million shares.
After the market closed on Thursday, Oracle, based in Redwood Shores, Calif., said profit from operations rose to $193 million, or 29 cents a share, matching analysts' estimates.
More importantly, Oracle said revenue in Europe -- a weak spot for the past few quarters -- rose 28 percent in the quarter, better than analysts expected.
"Their business is going strong again on all fronts," said Bruce Raabe, at brokerage Collins & Co. in San Francisco. "There's still certainly lots of demand for Oracle products in Europe."
Oracle has been reshaping its European operations to adjust to weaker economic conditions there. The effort is paying off, company executives told analysts on Thursday.

Oracle also said it was on track to deliver a new version of its flagship database product by June. Once the new programme, Oracle8, is introduced, customers would likely buy it "fairly aggressively," Raabe said.
At least one closely watched Wall Street analyst, Drew Brosseau of Cowen & Co., upgraded his rating on Oracle's stock, based on the strong performance in the quarter.
In recent weeks, Oracle shares have slid because of concerns about the company's European performance and possible delays in the shipment of Oracle8.
